content:
Hi. This question may not really be too formalization related, so apologies if it belongs more elsewhere --

In this podcast episode: at around 14 minutes https://kpknudson.com/my-favorite-theorem/2021/1/15/episode-62-tai-danae-bradley the speaker is talking about a sort of category theory-ish interpretation or connection with the singular value decomposition from linear algebra, but I can't quite get enough googleable words to figure out where to read about what she's talking about. In particular I guess I want to know specifically what she means when she says that the property you want to preserve when multiplying (at 16:10) is not linearity and instead has something to do with the set structure, but she doesn't say what it is. Any suggestion on what to read for more detail?

(I know negative amounts of information about category theory other than basic definitions...)

No idea but my googling yielded https://twitter.com/math3ma/status/1345411561989361664?s=19

Under this dictionary, I like to think of “enriched profunctor nuclei” as analogous to “the singular vectors of a matrix.” In this way, “the ubiquity of enriched profunctor nuclei” parallels the ubiquity of singular value decomposition throughout mathematics! https://twitter.com/math3ma/status/1345411561989361664/photo/1

- Tai-Danae Bradley (@math3ma)
Oh, nice, thanks! I thought to look at her blog but not twitter.
Yeah I think the structure she's referring to is a profunctor

Aha, thanks! That also helps produce some related-looking-still-understandable results. (Which she sure enough says explicitly in https://twitter.com/math3ma/status/1351681223899443210 )

Some of the category theory I alluded to in the latest @myfavethm episode is what we’ll be exploring in the Adjoint School! (I tried to motivate "profuctor nuclei" w/o using those words. Turns out that's hard!) Applications still open - deadline Jan 29! https://kpknudson.com/my-favorite-theorem/2021/1/15/episode-62-tai-danae-bradley https://twitter.com/math3ma/status/1345411263208165376

- Tai-Danae Bradley (@math3ma)

@Julian Berman her thesis is very readable. And it sounds like a lot of these ideas are from ch 5 there.

https://arxiv.org/abs/2004.05631
